title: On 1 March 2021, how many states will have a COVID-19 positivity rate greater than 10.0%?
preds: Only 3 states currently have a positivity rate greater than 10%
Revising based on latest data from COVID ActNow website, currently shows 3 states with a positivity rate above 10%.

There will most likely be only 3 states with a >10% positivity rate on 1st March.
Texas, New Hampshire, Oklahoma 
The data moves quite quickly and positivity looks to be falling in the mains.
Good news !

We are now down to just four states being above 10%, with one state within one 1% point.  The other three states that are closed to 10% are below 8.5%.  COVID cases have been dropping nationwide and none of the states that are close to 10% are seeing a rise in cases.  https://www-nytimes-com.nduezproxy.idm.oclc.org/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html
There are only four states at the moment that have positivity rates greater than 10%.  The is an incredibly low likelihood that 9 states will have a rate of over 10% in a few days.
There are currently 4 states above a 10% positivity rate, and another 8 above 8%.  With current trends, I don't expect the number of states to exceed eight by 1 March.

Currently, 4 states have a >10% positivity rate. Only South Carolina  and Kentucky  are within .5%  of the 10% threshold South Carolina [ pop 5.15M ]
-Would need 257500 new cases, or .5% of population to get over 10% positivity
--CDC daily 7-day moving average for new cases in South Carolina is approx. 1663/day Kentucky [pop 4.47M ]
-Would need 223500 new cases, or .5% of population to get over 10% positivity
-CDC daily 7-day moving average for new cases in Kentucky is approx. 1178/day There will be only 4 states with a >10% positivity rate on 1st March.
New Hampshire, Oklahoma, Texas & Mississippi
Cases and the positivity rates continue to drop
Currently there are 11 states with positivity rates higher than 10%. Therefore, this is unlikely to change. Some are close to the 10% threshold, hence the 30% possibility.
8 states with <10%.  Top 12 states with highest positivity rate are all declining or significantly declining or significantly declining.

Currently 5 states over 10%, Utah at 9.9%, and 4 more between 9.8% and 9.0% (inclusive).  Of the top ten states (all at >=9%, only two have infection rates over .90 (SC and NH which are 18.9% and 13.7% respectively on positivity). Most likely outcome appears to be 8 (upper limit of the lower tier). Will be watching this one closely for the next few days.

29 states now seeing short increases.
Up to 6 states with 10% or higher. The short term trend is undeniably up from there. Nonetheless, the longer term pattern is for reduced numbers. What happens over the next few days will be very interesting.

Adjusting numbers down significantly towards a much higher probability for 8 or less states:
- only 4 states with positivity rate greater than 10% (as of 2/20/2021)
- 77% drop in cases in past 6 weeks according to this WSJ piece (https://www.wsj.com/articles/well-have-herd-immunity-by-april-11613669731)
- just over a week remaining on this question

There are currently 4 states with a positivity rate greater than 10%.  With case numbers and rates decreasing across the country, this trend is expected to continue as more individuals are vaccinated.  Additionally, with winter weather hammering much of the country, people haven't been going outside to mix and mingle, lowering their chances of contracting coronavirus.

Cases are plummeting across the country as the U.S. has hit its post-holiday COVID high.  https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/02/05/us/covid-peak-comparison.html And right now, there are just four states above the 10% threshold.  In just under two weeks, that number has decreased from 15.   Additionally, just three states have had more cases in the last week: North Dakota, South Dakota, and Nebraska.  And none of those states are anywhere near the 10% threshold.    https://www.axios.com/health/coronavirus/  So it seems like all the signs are pointing towards this being 8 or fewer.  So I'm going heavy in 8 or fewer, but keeping a little bit in the 9-15.  I just don't see how we can get to the 16-22 or more at this point. What could cause this nationwide decreasing trend to change?  Biden has made numerous statements about the need for schools to reopen to in-person learning.  It's possible that kids returning to school could cause a new spike.  However, studies generally show that kids do not transmit the disease, so I don't think this is going to cause a major spike.  Second, if you look at the states that are still >10% positive per test, those same states also have lower infection rates.  Third, the CDC has been making more statements about the need to "double-mask" whenever possible, so it seems like that is probably helping to minimize transmission as well. Also, it seems clear based on the NY Times article that there have been two clear "cycles" for COVID positivity.  The first was the initial hump in the Spring of 2020 and the second was the Christmas holiday.  Using history as a lense through which to predict the future, as suggested by Richard E. Neustadt and Ernest R. May (Thinking In Time: the Uses Of History For Decision Makers)  or William Strauss and Neil Howe (The Fourth Turning: an American Prophecy) it seems like we may still have one more hump to hit.  The Spanish Flu had three distinct peaks before herd immunity was reached.  https://www.cdc.gov/flu/pandemic-resources/1918-commemoration/three-waves.htm  But that peak will not hit in the  next two weeks.

19 of the states now seeing small increases. This is up from 15 yesterday and 12 the previous day. Suggestive of a slow down, but still too early to be thinking too much into it. Many states are increasing and/or slowing down from very low values.
seems like we're coming down off of recent peaks.  need to find a better website with data.

I have maintained the probabilities, but will be watching carefully. 15 states have seen small upticks in the test positivity, up from 12 yesterday. Utah has jumped back above 10%. The overall trend is down, but there are early signs of a change of momentum.

The crowd is tending more and more towards option 1.
Currently only 8 states have this rate and the trend is towards decreasing numbers of cases.
Significant downward trend continues along with nation-wide decrease in overall number of cases.
only 4 states have a positive rate above 10% right now and cold weather pulse storms are keeping people at home

4 states currently have a rate above 10%. 6 States have a rate between 9 and 10%. 8 states have a rate above 9.5%. All 8 of the highest positivity states are experiencing a significant downward trend in cases. Therefore, I think that it is unlikely that 4 of the states will rise above 10%.

Currently 5 states are included in this number. The states nearing 10% have seen actively decreasing numbers, and it is highly unlikely that 4 or more states will see sudden outbreaks sufficient enough to push them over this threshold.

There are currently 6 states at or above 10.0% This number was previously at 8 and has since decreased because Utah and Kentucky dipped to 9.9% and 9.8%, respectively. I think these numbers will continue to dip and the total will be 8 or fewer, even if one or two states experience a jump.

According to COVID Act Now, only 8 states have a 10% or greater positivity rate. Given the current downward case trends and multiple states' closeness to 10%, there will likely be less than 8 states still with positivity rates greater than 10%.
https://covidactnow.org/?s=1597539
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/cases-updates/forecasts-cases.html#:~:text=Interpretation%20of%20Forecasts%20of%20New%20Cases&text=This%20week's%20national%20ensemble%20predicts,week%20ending%20March%206%2C%202021.

The data show a dramatic lowering in positivity rates from my initial forecast (8 states > 10% compared to the original 15 states).  All research indicates the virus remains as (if not more) contagious, so the shift has to be a result of fewer positive patients getting tested or more negative patients getting tested.  Some epidemiologists and public health experts argue this is a result of decreased emphasis on testing and increased emphasis on vaccination (https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/02/14/why-coronavirus-cases-are-dropping/).  Under this theory, people who should be getting tested are simply waiting to get the vaccine instead.  If this is correct, the downward trend would continue for the next two weeks until the end of the forecast period.  Regardless of the cause, the data have shifted enough from my initial forecast to warrant an update.
Dropped to 7 states. Downward trend is now significant. It would be very surprising to reverse that before the end of the month

This continues to trend downward. Currently there are 8 states meeting the condition. Increased testing and increased distribution of the vaccine should prevent the number from increasing significantly.
10 states at above 10, with one of them at 10.1 and 10.3, trending down.
With cases dropping dramatically and an increase in daily vaccinations, and as of today only 10 states above the 10% threshold, it seems likely that 8 or fewer states will have a 10% positive rate.
updating to reflect the downward swing brought on by winter weather.

With the COVID-19 cases decreasing across the country, it seems like fewer states will have a positive test rate above 10%.  There are currently 10 states with positive test rates above 10%, but 5 of those states are at 10.0%-10.6%.  Assuming the rates continue to decline over the next few weeks, these states are expected to drop below 10.0%.
Down to 10 states, and decreasing values in most states. Still early to be too confident.
Down from 12 to 11 states today.  With 18 days remaining I think we will see "8 or fewer."

14 states with this positively rate as of today and only 2 weeks until deadline. Tennessee likely to drop out of the criteria or S. Carolina likely to move up, so 13-15 is the most reasonable conclusion to me.
Down to 12. I'd expect Georgia, Utah Arizona and Mississippi to drop below soon and none to come up. Willl update in circa 1 week or earlier if data comes sooner

There are still 15 states with a test rate >10%, but these numbers are trending downwards according to the Axios article.  I'm going to take some % away from the 23-29 category and plus up my 9-15 category, as there seems to be little chance of 8 states increasing their numbers above 10%.
Slight lowering of the percentage for 8 or fewer. The numbers are fairly unresponsive and progress will be slow and there are only 22 days left

With 23 days to go the numbers aren't changing very much.  Not only has the number of states meeting the criterion not changed, sitting at 15 for a full week, but the positivity rates for the top 10 states haven't fallen much.  I'm moving some chips from the bottom bucket to "Between 16 and 22."  Sometimes it pays to play defense.

New Update: Expecting the 7 day rolling average of new cases to fall to 90-100k per day by March 1st. Expecting daily tests to fall to 800k per day. So the average test positivity rate for US should drop to ~11-12.5% from current level of 14%. That is giving me 11-13 states with test positivity above 10% on March 1st. Adjusting my forecasts accordingly.

Only been tracking properly for two days. 15 states currently over 10%. 10 of those have reduced their rates in the past two days, 37 states have reduced their rates. Of those that haven't decreased from over 10%, in all cases the numbers are still the same [most likely from a lack of an update].
It seems very unlikely that more than 15 states will have 10% or higher positivity rates.
Will keep tracking.

Currently at 15 states above 10, 28 above 8.  I expect the rate of new cases to decrease, but may also result in overall less testing, which would keep the positivity rate higher than if the same number of tests were performed.  Therefore, I expect a similar number of states with a positivity rate above 10% on 1 March.

15, 1
I'm not sure how it went from 11 states up to 15 states when only one state has an infection rate if 1.0 or more. testing must be declining. They must be testing fewer asymptomatic people.

It looks like things are better than my initial forecast.  So I am going to take some % away from the 16-22 and adjust downward. According to a recent Axios report: New coronavirus infections fell by 16% over the past week — the third straight week of significant improvement.  In 41 states, the average number of new daily cases was lower over the past week than the week before. No states got worse.  I've also learned from some of the questions I have forecasted on that have already closed out that there truly is wisdom in the crowd.  So I'm adjusting downward for that reason as well.
https://www.axios.com/coronavirus-cases-infections-decline-variants-b17d4f5d-e3c0-4768-b489-f45548f2f56f.html
Adjusting based on 15 states currently having a COVID-19 positivity rate greater than 10.0% and this number will likely drop.

Daily test numbers have declined significantly for the last three days.  I have no idea why.  But if test numbers continue to trend lower the percent positives won't decline as much.  Moving some chips from "8 or fewer" to "Between 9 and 15."
Down to 15 states. Still very early and some states are close. I expect the number to keep reducing though.

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has been below 1.00 for two weeks, and now stands at 0.856.  The 7-day average of new infections has been falling an average of a couple of percent per day for most states.  If the average Rt remains well under 1.00 for 26 more days, admittedly not a certainty, the number of positives should decline by about half. Test numbers have remained around 1.8 M/day for 2 1/2 months now, so I will bet that the number of tests will remain roughly constant.  Under the above assumptions the percent positives should continue down, and fewer states should exceed the 10.0% threshold.

Trying to anticipate the trend a little bit. I was pessimistic on testing, but it does seem like states have been dropping so testing is a little better than I thought and it does seem like the high test rates were a big part a function of high case rates and not just inadequate testing.

- Updating forecast to include overall decreasing positivity rate trend, therefore lowering 30+ and 23-29 outcomes, while raising 16-22 and 9-15.  
- Unsure how the new variant will impact testing requirements within the next 30 days, but would think the new variant being more contagious may require additional testing IF it spreads in the US.
- https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-orders-factbox-idUSKBN29Y2QN describes the executive order putting COVID response at the federal level in more proactive role in supporting states with vaccine and testing.
- will look look for signposts over next few weeks regarding State decisions on testing and ease of restrictions, and any announcements at federal level or state level regarding testing supplies and laboratory congestion (an issue in some states).

- Currently there are 15 states > 10% positivity rate, and 28 states > 8%. 
- Trend has been heading down following spike after holidays, however, we've typically under forecasted COVID-19 related "bad" stuff.
- Vaccines are rolling out, but some states have also been rolling back restrictions, so will be interesting to see how states understand how vaccination rates impact the ability to spread the virus, how they should change testing (if at all), and how soon they will relax existing social protection measures.

As others have pointed out, it looks like 15 states are at 10% or higher as of today. According to the resource below, above 5% is considered a "rule of thumb" for being considered too high, implying that under improved testing (or increasing immunity) the positivity rate should go down.  https://www.jhsph.edu/covid-19/articles/covid-19-testing-understanding-the-percent-positive.html Taking a rough look at the monthly average for the past 3 month's from the covidactnow.org API data, 14 of the 15 states over 10% were over 10% and higher than the previous month and there are 3 states under 10% that are trending towards 10%. Based on that analysis and the month remaining, I think there's a 60% probability that there will be 16-22 states with a 10% positivity rate. I was unable to find information on state access to testing so I was reluctant to increase the probability that there would be 9 to 15 states with over 10% positivity under improved testing.

Right now, there are 15 states with a positive test rate of >10%. This number really relies on two things:  the number of positive tests divided by the number of tests. - Now, what can affect how many positive tests there are?  - the vaccine roll-out (the more people vaccinated, the less positive tests, assuming those tests aren't checking for antibodies), people mixing together and not social distancing (this seems unlikely, as the weather warms more people will be outside, there are no holidays to driver gatherings, etc) - What can drive the number of tests given?  If the vaccine is rolled out, people will be less likely get tested because they will assume they have immunity.  Only those that are REALLY sick will get tested. Regarding the number of 15 states, is where we exist right now on 31 January higher, lower, or in line with history?  This site provides some REALLY good historical data, but it will take to dig through it: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/testing/individual-states/ After going through the JHU website, I did a quick glance to divide states into one of three categories:  1) a state that has consistently been >10%, 2) a state that has flopped above and below 10%, 3) states that have consistently been below 10%. After doing that, I came up with 14 consistently above 10%, 15 that bounce above and below, and 22 that have been consistently less than 10%.  So generally speaking, its seems like the number of states above 10% is on the decline.  Therefore, I'm going to weight 9-15 as the highest, with zero for 30 or more.  I just don't see that many states spiking to >10%. Now I need to look at the wisdom of the crowd and adjust accordingly:  I'm in the ballpark with the crowd.  I'll adjust 1-2% in each direction to account for the crowd. So we really looking at those 15 that could be above or below as the swing states.  Let's just say half are above, and half are below.   That would put us at 23 states.

Base Rate:
Currently, 15 states have a positivity rate great than 10%.  The source referenced in the question (COVID ActNow) determines the “Positive Test Rate” as the number of tests administered ÷ the number of positive tests, both as reported by the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).  This definition is significant because it only includes people who choose to get tested, not the state’s total population.  Assuming the COVID virus does not dramatically mutate over the next four weeks, we should expect roughly the same percentage of people who test will come back positive.  Therefore, my outside view remains the same as the current level: 15 states. Inside View Adjustments:
National Trend Data.  Using the same HHS dataset, the national average (average of all state’s positivity rate) is 8.4% with a standard deviation of 3.7%.  According to the CDC, the national two-week average positive test rate is 11%, down from 12% for the previous two-week average (I could not find this data from HHS).  There are four weeks before the end of the forecast period.  Assuming the HHS state-level positive rate data follows the CDC’s national trend, positive test rates would drop 1% every two weeks.  This would lower the HHS average to 6.4% by 1 March.  Assuming a distribution similar to the current data, I would still expect 13 states to report a positive test rate above 10%. Vaccinations.  The U.S. administered the first COVID vaccination on 14 December 2020.  After some initial logistical issues, by mid-January, 900,000 Americans received the COVID vaccine each day (roughly 0.27% of the US population).  Even after receiving the vaccine, patients can still contract the virus and test positive for up to 28 days.  However, individuals who receive the vaccine are probably much less likely to get a COVID test within the four weeks after vaccination.  This is likely already contributing to the 1% per two-week decline noted in the CDC data. Considering these inside view factors, my forecast is 13 states.

Today 15 (22 2 days ago)
Decrease.
The re-emergence of the epidemic due to new variants can be compensated for by vaccines, weather, and restrictive measures.
There are now 18 states that match this criteria. For the reasons in my original post, I'm revising the number down.

Today 22
Decrease. 
The re-emergence of the epidemic due to new variants can be compensated for by vaccines, weather, and restrictive measures.

Outside View: On 1/28, 22 states had a positive test rate greater than 10% (Louisiana right at 10%). Data I’ve found at the national level show positivity rates from about 8.7 to 9.3, depending on the source. The trend shows a national peak just after the new year of 13.7 positivity rate, followed by a reasonably steep decline. At this time it looks like the curve is settling out. Based on the trend data, my estimate is for about a 1% decrease in the positivity rate by March 1. Inside View: Although the vaccine is rolling out, this should not affect the positive rate much, as it is rolling out slowly, and primarily to elderly or at risk americans. Perhaps the overall positivity rate drops as much as .5% due to the vaccine and people who may be more likely to contract covid having antibodies. Next, as more of the population, especially those who are vulnerable, have had COVID, there is a smaller population that doesn’t have covid antibodies. One article I’ve read suggests as many as 1/3 Americans have COVID antibodies. Finally, I don’t see many more lockdowns being put in place, and the weather is still forcing many indoors during winter, so I am discounting these factors from a large impact on the overall positivity rate. Synthesis: Between the outside view and inside view, my synthesis estimate is for an overall decrease nationally in the positivity rate of 2%. Although imperfect, a decrease in 2% of the positivity rate would mean 6 less states above 10%. Thus my estimate is for 16 states with a positivity rate of 10% or more.  Unfortunately, 16 is split between the 9-15 and 16-22 groupings. So I’m going to give 16-22 a 65% chance, and 9-15 a 35% chance. 1 Feb update, new data shows only 15 states currently, updating to 30% 8 or fewer, 65% 9-15, 5% 16-22.

The new National Strategy says testing is a cornerstone to reducing the spread of COVID-19. World Health Organization has said a positive test rate of less than 5 percent may indicate that a community is conducting enough testing to find most cases. If a state has a high test positivity rate, it is a sign of insufficient testing. These point to the need and political will to conduct more tests. 
 
There are currently 23 states at 10% positivity rate or higher. Since I assume an increase in the number of tests being administered, I do not believe the number of states above 10% will increase. 
 
The current national 7-day moving average of positivity rates is 9.1% and this rate has fallen steadily from 13.7% earlier in January. This seems to indicate a sustainable downward trend in positivity despite the number of daily tests being conducted holding relatively steady in January. I assume this downward trend will continue when you factor in additional testing capacity covering a wider sampling of the population. I believe this make the 9-15 category most likely.

Today 23
Convinced by the rational of @JamesEE

Skewing slightly toward the lower end as the count is now 23 with about a month to go. I still see the lowest bucket of this as somewhat unlikely since testing has not been at adequate levels to get low positivity rates in all the states.
We're down to 22 today.  If test numbers remain roughly constant, and infection rates fall by about a third, we should be down to 8-10 states by March 1.

After being stuck at 28 for nearly one week, the number of states >10.0% has dropped to 25.  A key question is whether or not test numbers will remain the same, or possibly even increase.  If we continue to focus testing on symptomatic patients the percent positivity won't fall much.  If we do more random sampling, or blanket testing at e.g., universities, the positivity rate should fall significantly. How much will the biden administration emphasize increased testing, and how quickly could it be implemented?  I doubt there could be a significant testing ramp-up before March 1.  I'll bet that testing won't change over the next 5 weeks -- it hasn't changed much over the past two months. I note that @jainsa (who has a very good prediction record) is forecasting a drop to 1.1M tests per day.  With that assumption he thinks we'll be at 16 states on March 1.  If testing remains around 1.8 M/day the number of states should be lower.  I'll go with lower on this one.

Expecting the 7 day rolling average of new cases to fall to 120k per day by March 1st. Expecting daily tests to fall to 1.1 million per day. So the average test positivity rate for US should drop by about 1/4th of current levels. That is giving me 16 states with test positivity above 10% on March 1st. Adjusting my forecasts accordingly.
Currently 28. B117 has yet to have a significant impact.

28, 7
Dropped 4 states in five days and based on the infection rates, many more States will fall below 10% quickly. This is clearly following the normal flu season curve. 5 days ago 36 States had an infection rate of 1.0 or more, now it is seven.

Down to 28, and one would expect it to slowly decrease. Does anyone know of how we can neatly plot case positivity by state in time? Is there an available data download?
I'm currently having to base the shape of the pandemic on the case rates, not the positivity for this question.
Adjusting for higher current rate, but assuming it's reached peak and will trend down
Coming up on 30 or more and the higher buckets as the current number is 31 and has been mostly unchanged since late December.

32 above 10%, 36 1.0 or more infection rate
We've dropped five states in five days. Things have turned the corner and are now trending down. It's just a case of how far it can decline in the next 6 weeks. this is maybe partially from immunizations, but more than that I think this is simply following the normal flu season schedule.

New infections as well as Rt numbers (https://rt.live) are headed down now.  I'll bet on a continuation of this trend. Immunity from infection is still much greater than immunity from vaccination.  But by March 1 the effect of vaccinations should be visible in the data. See https://covid19-projections.com/path-to-herd-immunity/.
@jainsa convinced me to be more optimistic.  I tend to go in that direction anyway, but this time I needed a little nudge.

As I was expecting, the rolling average of the daily new cases has flattened in mid-January (in fact it ~7% below the peak level [1]). I think this is going to be local maxima.  I am expecting the new case numbers to start decreasing now as the impact of holidays is behind us.  I think the 7 day rolling average will fall to ~100-150k per day by 1st of March. That should mean ~20 states above threshold of 10% positivity [1] https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-10-28..latest&country=~USA&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=desc
We are a long way out, and currently over 30. However one would expect a small amount of control to be enacted. Can't be certain though.

We've been above 30, or just below it, since Thanksgiving.  So far my forecast that the number would drop has not panned out.  A rapid increase in testing could bring the number down, or the fast-spreading B.1.1.7 mutation could cause an increase.  I'll shift away from my optimistic forecast to a more equal weighting for all the bins.

today: 38
Contrary to my last prediction, none of the factors mentioned seem to diminish the intensity of the epidemic.
There is no reason to think that things will improve significantly in the coming weeks.
In addition, I tend to be overly optimistic in my previous forecast about COVID, compared to reality and other forecasters.

Currently US test positivity rate ~ 15% and its trending up. Its possible to decrease it by 5-10% in 50 days as done by other countries in past like France, Italy etc. But 1st we have to start moving in the right direction. Till we do that, I am moving weightages towards higher bins.
As of 13-01-2021: 33 states
Results somehow as expected by this time, positivity rate increasing and more States moving into the higher than 50% test rate. Let's see what happens in a week.

I've been discounting the higher ranges.  Now I have to admit that the new virus mutations (esp. B.1.1.7) could send the numbers higher at the end of February.  It's a race between the mutating virus and the vaccine machine.  So far it appears the vaccine machine is sputtering, allowing the virus to advance.  It's time to hedge my bets.

Redistributing more evenly. I'm hopeful that testing expands under Biden but it seems that we're not interested in testing beyond likely cases. Part of that is probably because we're at the peak of a wave, but even states that have reduced their prevalence are over 10%, so it seems like it's mostly a testing issue and not just a matter of being in a wave of cases.

According to covidactnow.org, the current number of states with a positivity rate over 10% is 29.  Given current trends, it seems likely that the number of states over 10% will remain constant or perhaps even increase in the coming weeks as the country struggles to produce an adequate quantity of test and vaccines, both of which would drive the positivity rate down.
Peak hit on 12/5 of 39 states. If curve follows first wave, roughly 14 states will have >10%.  14 is high due to July 4th wave. But, vaccination will help reduce.

Update. The number of States with +10% positivity rates is going down, consistent with the data. As States are doing more tests, rates are going down (some stay in the +10% as expected). 
Even the total number is lower, the evolution is into higher rates as result of gatherings, LA, NH and FL getting into +10%. It shouldn't last two month. Good article here [1].
Two elements to consider more closely: new variants and vaccines. On new variants, the British and South African mutations are, apparently, not more dangerous but a lot more contagious. Also, given how quickly they spread, we should consider a new, unknown variant as a possibility in the US, changing trends and increasing positivity rates.
On vaccines, how will rates move as more citizens are vaccinated? Some data can be taken from [2], but the program started so rencently that we cannot have any meaningful projections on results, not even for Israel [3] or Bahrain [4], the top 2 countries (not that they are comparable by population or density).
Anyway, two months might be a too short time to implement a huge logistic program like this and have improvements in the rate.
Combining negatives and lack of time to see results from positive, I move from 8 to 15 and 22. [1] https://www.economist.com/united-states/2020/11/28/the-midwest-is-americas-covid-19-hotspot
[2] https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations
[3] https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/il
[4] https://covid19.who.int/region/emro/country/bh
As of 4th Jan: there are 29 states above 10% out of which 10 are 15% or above
Currently 30. Eight states with infection rate over 1.0

At 30 now, but will go down as testing increases. Numbers is 10%+ means that only the sick and the ones who were in contact are tested. If people get tested for travel and other reasons, numbers should go down.
Also as more people are immune, testing of immediate contacts will also lower the positivity number.
If the pandemic continues to rage then it is likely to have sustained high levels balanced against vaccines uptake which will be well under way by February.

32 right now at the peak of a wave. I don't expect future waves to be this bad, as the severity will be reduced somewhat by immunity from virus spread and vaccine distribution. So I would be surprised to see any numbers above 30 after this, especially three months from now. That said, it's possible testing could get lax in some states which would result in a high positivity even if overall cases aren't as bad. So I'm putting 8 or fewer as most likely, but there's a decent chance for the larger categories.

1. More tests will be done.
2. The vaccine will begin to have an impact.

Currently, we have 32 states over 10%, plus VA and NP with zero. By having a look at the data [1], it seems that some of the results are due to low number of tests [2].
12 out of 13 states with less than 500K per Million Pop are showing more than 10% in Positive Rate (compared to 60/40 with more than 500K). So, some of the results are expected to improve as more tests are done.
For the states over 500K rate, the question then is if things will get worse before getting better.
Everything being the same, the trend seems to be descending, after a peak late Nov, mid Dec. Only a few states show Positive rate still growing, and probably not lasting more than two months.
It will be good to confirm this trend in the next few weeks.

It looks like there is a tend toward holding testing centers accountable and forcing them to report the number of cycles used and what the cutoff is. The CDC and WHO have both admitted that PCR testing can have large false positives. Florida is now requiring testing centers to report their cutoff levels and number of cycles, and I think it's likely other jurisdictions will follow that trend. This will result in many fewer positive cases. I tend to think it's not a coincidence that the testing methodology is changing at the same time that immunizations are becoming available. Also, the normal course for this disease is for it to drop off over the next 2 months.

• The number today is 31.
• Reported total daily US tests have flattened around 1.8 million for a couple of weeks.  More testing should drop the positivity rate.
• If testing numbers remain flat then the positivity rate will follow the new infection rate, which is currently going down for roughly half the states.
• Total new US infections seem to have reached a peak, at least temporarily.  They may resume their climb, but I'll bet on a downward trend.
• Starting with an optimistic forecast that favors the lower ranges.
The effects of the vaccine should start to show by this time.
